journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics

title-group.article-title: Optimization of semi-trailing arm suspension for improving handling and stability of passenger car

article-meta.aff: Mechanical Engineering Department, Shahid Chamran University, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mohsen Kazemi, Mechanical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Shahid Chamran University, Ahvaz, Iran. Email: kazemi.scu@gmail.com

abstract.p: Semi-trailing arm is an extended form of two suspension systems trailing arm and swing axle that compromises advantages and disadvantages of those systems. In this article, using Bees algorithm optimization method, the characteristic parameters of a semi-trailing arm suspension system to optimize the handling and stability performances of a passenger car are determined. Two types of objective functions, namely off-line and on-line, are defined. In off-line objective function, variation of camber, toe angle, and wheel track due to roll are considered. In the on-line objective function, handling and stability performance of a moving vehicle in a standard J-turn maneuver are considered. A nine degree-of-freedom non-linear vehicle model consists of semi-trailing arm and MacPherson suspensions in rear and front axle, respectively, is considered. The optimized suspension systems obtained from both off-line and on-line objective functions are utilized in making two accurate vehicle models in ADAMS-Car for experimental field test. A comparison between the behaviors of the two vehicles shows that despite the simplicity of optimization with off-line objective functions relative to on-line1, it returns the satisfactory results and improves both the handling and stability performances.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Today, the importance of suspension system on handling and stability performance of a vehicle is well-defined. Semi-trailing arm is one of the simplest types of independent mechanisms. This mechanism is an extension of trailing arm and swing axle mechanisms with the same number and type of links and joints. The latter mechanisms have opposite effects on vehicle dynamics. For example, in the trailing arm handling due to positive camber, variation is poor while the stability against rollover due to constant wheel track is good. In the swing axle suspension, the handling due to negative camber variation, is good while the stability due to jacking forces and scratching effect is poor.1,2 The semi-trailing arm compromises the advantage and disadvantage of both the mechanisms. Attia3 works on transient dynamic analysis of a vehicle with semi-trailing A-arm suspensions for front and rear of vehicle. He assesses vertical displacement and acceleration of mass center of vehicle due to two different simulations. In the first simulation, the motion of the vehicle is started from the rest position under the action of the gravitational force and wheel compression forces. In the second simulation, the vehicle is given an initial rolling angular velocity. Dixon4 performed kinematics of the semi-trailing mechanism due to bounce and rebound in wheel. He supposed that the roll center of mechanism is fixed, and proposed the approximate geometric model for assessing the kinematic of single arm suspension consist of trailing, swing and semi-trailing arm suspensions. Shenlin and Xinbo5 similarly evaluated kinetics of semi-trailing arm suspension based on the relationship between the rigidity of suspension and that of the coil spring as well as relationship between suspension damping coefficient. Azman et al.6 investigated the influence of anti-dive and anti-squat geometry in suspension on ride comfort performance. The investigations are concerned with a real vehicle and the numerical predictions show reasonable agreement with measurements obtained on an instrumented vehicle under the same maneuvers. Also, they investigated vehicle response for common maneuver over single speed bump, which is a non-trivial complex motion.7 One major aim of this article is to investigate the effect of the anti-roll bar upon vehicle dynamics. Fujita et al.8 discussed the design of vehicles using multi-link suspension system with the aim of totally optimizing vehicle’s handling and stability. The variation of toe angle and camber angle, roll center position, roll angle of the body under the steady-state circular turning and vertical vibration are selected as objective functions. For optimizing the multi-objective problem, the genetic algorithm (GA) has been utilized. Many research papers have concentrated on the optimization of suspension mechanisms to improve the handling and stability of vehicle. They have considered the variation of toe angle and camber angle as objective function. For example, Simionescum and Beale9 and Hwang et al.,10 respectively, worked on five links and double wishbone suspension mechanism. Habibi et al.11 optimized the characteristic parameters of MacPherson mechanism using GA for front axle of a vehicle. Naude and Steyn,12 investigated computer simulation of the handling characteristics of a vehicle performing a double lane change maneuver. Orlandea and Chace,13 dissected the front suspension mechanism using the ADAMS computer program. Hegazy et al.14 present a multidegree of freedom non-linear multibody dynamic model of a vehicle, comprising front and rear suspension, steering system, road wheels, tires, and vehicle inertia. By this model, they extended lateral acceleration overshoot, particularly on the inside wheels to provide a good measure of vehicle stability. In this article, improvement of a vehicle dynamic and stability with semi-trailing arm rear suspension and MacPherson strut for the front is investigated. The geometric dimensions of the semi-trailing arm are defined using characterized parameters. Then, finding the best characteristic parameters of the mechanism to improve the performances is defined in the form of an optimization problem. Two objective functions are defined, namely off-line and on-line. Bees algorithm (BA) is used as optimization method. Solution of the problem with off-line objective function returns a suspension with minimum variation of camber, toe and wheel track variation and solution with on-line objective function returns a suspension with minimum variation of vertical road forces on wheels contact patches and vertical force difference between the front and rear axles. Next, kinematics analysis of the semi-trailing arm suspension mechanism due to roll is determined. In ‘Non-linear vehicle model’ section, mathematical model of a nine degree-of-freedom (9-DOF) vehicle is derived. In ‘Objective functions’ section, the off-line as well as on-line objective functions are introduced. In ‘Multi-objective Bees alogrithm’ section, BA is used to solve two multi-objective optimization problems. In ‘Simulation and results’ section, two obtained solutions are utilized to build two accurate vehicle models in ADAMS-Car environment. Then, the models are used to compare the improvement of two optimized suspension systems in the vehicle performance. The final section contains concluding remarks.

sec.title: Kinematic analysis of the semi-trailing arm suspension mechanism
sec.p:
A schematic diagram of semi-trailing arm suspension mechanism is depicted in Figure 1. Point Ro is the roll center of the vehicle rear axle.1 The center of wheel (point OL) is attached to the body of vehicle by control arm. The control arm can rotate about three-dimensional extended axis ELW. Figure 1.
Semi-trailing arm suspension mechanism.

The geometric dimension of the mechanism is defined using five characteristic parameters including two angles α (trailing angle), βs, three distances e1, e2, and e3 that are longitudinal, lateral, and vertical distances of EL from the wheel contact patch, respectively. The height of roll center hRo can be calculated as follows1 (1)

It is assumed that the roll center is fixed during the body roll. Considering Figure 2, the roll of the body by amount of (ϕ), cause the point EL goes to its new position EL ' (the prime sign is used to emphasize on new position of a point) such that (2) where T1 0 is a transformation matrix from coordinate systems 1 to 0 (3) Figure 2.
Semi-trailing arm suspension when vehicle is rolling.
The control arm rotates (λ) around the axis ELW when the body rolls. As mentioned, the axis ELW is a three-dimensional extended axis and the transformation matrix T1 2 is calculated as follows15 (4)
where Vλ=1-cosλ, rx, ry, and rz are components of the unit vector of the axis ELW that can be calculated with respect to the Euler angles as follows (5)

As shown in Figure 3, coordinate system A is attached to ELW axis. Transformation matrix T0 A can be calculated as follows (6) New location of point OL in coordinate system 0 can be expressed as follows (7) Figure 3.

That the prime denotes the new location of each point and r→EL '/OL ' can be evaluated by (8)

The amplitude of rotation control arm (λ) should be computed, as the contact patch point (PL) is not separated from the road surface when the body is rolling. As shown in Figure 3, the relationship between ϕ and λ can be determined by the following supposition:
‘The circle of the wheel should be tangent with the intersection of two planes of wheel and road.’
By computing the λ (Appendix 3), the normal vector of wheel surface (n→WL) can be calculated as follows (9)
Then, camber angle (γL) and toe angle (δL) would be computed as (10) (11)
As above, camber angle and toe angle of right wheel can be calculated. The track is expressed as (12)
where rPLy and rPRy are the components of the left and right wheel contact patch vector relative to roll center in y-direction on reference coordinate.

sec.title: Kinematics of the vehicle model
sec.p:
To establish an accurate model of the vehicle, a 9-DOF model is considered. The model’s DOF consists of three angular motions (roll, pitch, and yaw) of the sprung mass, spin of the wheels, and two translational motions (forward and side travel) of the unsprung mass. The center of sprung and unsprung mass of the vehicle (Os and Ou) is shown in Figure 4(a). Figure 4.
(a) Center of mass of the different parts of vehicle body and (b) sideslip angle of front and right wheels.
The longitudinal and lateral acceleration of the unsprung mass (X· and Y·) can be calculated as follows (13)
The absolute longitudinal and lateral acceleration of unsprung mass can be expressed as follows (14)

The vector a→Os is derived using summation of a→Ou, the relative acceleration a→Os/Ou, the Coriolis acceleration a→C=2ψ·k∧×v→Os/Ou, and track components a→Trac=(a→Trac)n+(a→Trac)t as follows (15) where Ai, Aj, and Ak components are explained in ‘The sprung mass center acceleration’ section (Appendix 2) and r→=ψ·k∧. From these acceleration components, the inertia forces of the vehicle body and the unsprung mass part can be expressed as follows (16)
Similarly, the moments are given as (17)

sec.p:

sec.title: Objective functions
sec.p: As mentioned in ‘Introduction’ section, the characterized parameters of the semi-trailing arm suspension mechanism are obtained through an optimization process. The objective functions are computed in two ways, namely off-line and on-line.

sec.title: Off-line objective functions
On-line objective functions
sec.p: In on-line objective functions, the handling and stability factors are directly measured from fishhook maneuver. Two types of objective functions based on the kinematic as well as kinetic of a moving vehicle in cornering maneuver are selected. This selection helps us to compare the performance of vehicle which suspension system is designed based on the kinematic criteria with that of kinetic criteria. The kinematic based objective functions are called on-line type 1 or on-line1 and the kinetic based, on-line type 2 or on-line2.

sec.title: On-line1 objective function
sec.p: To examine the handling performance, a desired yaw rate can be computed during the maneuver based on the driver’s steering input and vehicle speed as follows18 (25) in which Ku is zero, negative, or positive for neutral, oversteer, or understeer cornering, respectively, and given as (26) where Cj, j=f,r is the cornering stiffness and can be derived by calculating the slope of (Fyi-αi) diagram at αi = 0 (27) where Fiy,i=fR,fL,rR,rL are the lateral forces. Differentiating equation (18), we have (28)
Substituting equation (28) into equation (27) yields (29)
Hence, the on-line1 objective functions are introduced as follows (30) where tmax is the duration of the associated cornering maneuver.

sec.title: On-line2 objective function
sec.p: The mathematical explanations of the criteria are as follows (31)

sec.title: Multi-objective BA
sec.p:
Different techniques to solve multi-objective function optimization and their characteristics are explained in the study of Deb.22 Pham et al.23 have developed a new optimization tool, called the BA and have applied it to constrained and unconstrained single objective function optimization. Then, Pham and Ghanbarzadeh24 introduced the Multi-objective BA and showed the robust performance of the BA. The algorithm requires a number of parameters to be set, namely, number of scout bees (n), number of sites selected for neighborhood search (m), and number of bees recruited for the other (m) selected sites (nsp). The algorithm starts with (n) scout bees randomly distributed in the search space. The fitness of the sites visited by the scout bees is evaluated. The (m) non-dominated sites are designated as ‘selected sites’ and chosen for neighborhood search. Next, the representative bee will be the original one unless it is dominated by one of the recruited ones. Then, if the fittest is a non-dominated solution, it will be added to the Pareto optimal set. In addition, if this solution has dominated the other solutions in the performed Pareto optimal set, the dominated ones will be removed from the set. In the next step, the remaining bees in the population are placed randomly around the search space to scout for new potential solutions. These steps are repeated until a stopping criterion is met.17 Figure 7 shows the BA chart. Figure 7.
The multi-objective BA chart.

sec.title: Simulation and results
sec.p:
During the simulation, the driver’s input command follows from the diagram depicted in Figure 8. This input provides a cornering maneuver, namely the fishhook turn. The longitudinal velocity of vehicle during maneuvers is u=20 (m/s). The slope of the linear parts of the driver’s command and other parameters of the diagram in Figure 8 are S1=1 (rad/s) and S2=-1 (rad/s).25,26 Figure 8.
Front wheel steer in fishhook turn.

Figure 9(a) to (d) illustrates the Pareto solutions of the off-line objective functions. The non-dominated solutions contain wide range of the three cost functions in f1, f2, and f3 in equation (24). In Figure 9(a), the solutions that have smaller value than 0.1 in f2 in equation (24), the f1 in equation (24) can change between −8.75 and 13.75. In this region, the solutions that have f2 about −8 express the trailing arm mechanism and the solutions that have f2 greater than 6, express the swing axle mechanism. As shown in Figure 9(b), the track in swing axle mechanism due to rolling is reduced leads to the reduction of the rollover prevention in the vehicle. Variation of camber angle and toe angle of mechanisms A and B that are depicted in Figure 9(a) are negligible. Characteristic parameters of the semi-trailing arm suspension mechanism are limited in the ranges that are presented in Table 1. As shown in Figure 9(c), in solutions that have positive f3, variation of the toe angle (f2 in equation (24)) is large that can effect on handling performance in vehicle. Figure 9.
The Pareto solutions in off-line objective function. Table 1.
Bounds of design variables.
Specifications Characteristics parameters
α (°) βs (°) e1 (m) e2 (m) e3 (m)
Lower bound 0 −45 0 0 0
Upper bound 90 45 0.8 0.7 0.7

Figure 10(a) and (b) shows the Pareto solutions of the on-line1 and on-line2 objective function relatively. By reducing the value of the error of handling performance (g1 in equation (30) and h1 in equation (31)), the lateral stability of vehicle (g2 in equation (30) and h2 in equation (31)) is weakened. Figure 10.
The Pareto solutions in: (a) kinematic on-line objective function and (b) kinetic on-line objective function.

In Table 2, the parameters of A–F mechanisms that shown in Figures 9 and 10 are presented. Table 2.
Parameters of A–F optimized mechanisms.
α (°) βs (°) e1(m) e2(m) e3(m)
A (off-line) 21.411 3.845 0.279 0.1 0.2
B (off-line) 0 0 0.459 0.289 0.302
C (on-line1) 5.344 0.758 0.785 0.222 0.269
D (on-line1) 16.844 1.341 0.138 0.274 0.352
E (on-line2) 47.479 9.714 0.297 0.284 0.396
F (on-line2) 2.311 8.94 0.201 0.292 0.245

Figure 11 shows the camber angle, toe angle of left wheel, and track variations of A–F mechanisms that are shown in Figures 9 and 10 due to roll. Figure 11.
(a) Camber angle, (b) toe angle of left wheel, and (c) track variation with the roll angle.

The camber angle variation of A and D mechanisms look similar, but the toe angle and track variations of them are not exactly alike. Toe angle variation of B and C mechanisms is very close to zero, but camber angle variation has more than the considered mechanisms.

sec.title: Suspension effect on vehicle fishhook maneuver
sec.p:
In order to investigate the effect of semi-trailing arm on vehicle, a fishhook maneuver by vehicle model in ADAMS\Car software is utilized. The vertical force on critical wheel in maneuver for six mechanisms that are shown in Table 2 is indicated in Figure 12. Figure 12.
Vertical force in critical wheel in fishhook maneuver.

As shown in Figure 12, mechanisms C and D, which have been optimized based on kinematic on-line cost function makes minimum and maximum variation from static situation relatively. This means that kinematic on-line cost function includes the other considered mechanisms. Table 3 expresses the maximum longitudinal velocity of the vehicle by each considered mechanism in which rollover in vehicle (vrollover) occurs. Table 3.
Rollover velocity of vehicle with each mechanism.
Mechanism A (off-line) Mechanism B (off-line) Mechanism C (on-line1) Mechanism D (on-line1) Mechanism E (on-line2) Mechanism F (on-line2)
vrollover (km/h) 81.67 73.12 69.45 83.11 76.62 79.24

Figure 13 illustrates that the yaw rate of vehicle body with mechanisms D, F, and A make understeer behavior and mechanisms B, C, and E can exhibit an oversteer behavior. Figure 13.
Yaw rate of vehicle in fishhook maneuver.

As expected and shown in Figure 10(a), the mechanisms C and D improve the stability and handling performance relatively. From Figure 13, A and D mechanisms have elicited understeer behavior in vehicle but, as expressed in Table 3, B and C mechanisms augment the rollover propensity in vehicle. So, by this comparison and from Figure 11(a), camber angle variation due to roll in semi-trailing arm suspension, improve the handling performance of vehicle and weaken the stability. Accordingly, the designer can choose from the set of Pareto solutions with trade off between stability and handling performance of the vehicle.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this article, improvement of handling and stability of passenger car by the optimization of semi-trailing arm suspension is considered. For this purpose, three sets of cost functions based on the kinematics of semi-trailing arm mechanism due to roll, kinematic and kinetic of 9-DOF vehicle model due to fishhook maneuver, are considered. To optimize the introduced three cost functions, the multi-objective BA is used. The results show that using the on-line cost function, based on the kinematic of vehicle behavior for optimization, include the other cost functions.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
